stream_context.summary: Kaze integrates Biobak’s updated Course 10 (C10) rework assets, debugs recurring Fast64/export issues (palette/duplicate texture names, environment color constraints), and continues engine/performance cleanups (zero compiler warnings, fewer engine bugs). He also fixes/partially fixes Yoshi interaction/animation problems, tweaks visual variation via primitive color multipliers, discusses F3DEX3-based automatic patching, and realizes a full collision remap is needed due to moved geometry (likely finished off-stream).
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains meaningful engine/performance philosophy (instruction cache behavior, actor ordering), concrete tooling constraints (Fast64 environment color disabled, export/palette issues, F3DEX3 auto patching), collaboration touchpoints with Biobak, plus production/business notes (merch strategy, F3 2025 event idea).

findings.summary: Kaze announces a new merch store on TeePublic (cheaper than Spreadshirt) and plans a design for every course using the final game’s course icons; YouTube Studio integration may take up to two days.

Kaze resumes work on Biobak’s Course 10 (C10) rework via a new changelog with numerous actor/asset changes, importing updated files and iterating on visuals and gameplay objects based on Biobak’s feedback (e.g., color/brightness/outlines, collapse-floor behavior).

A recurring “texture has too many colors”/material export error reappears; Kaze traces it to a practical pipeline issue (two textures sharing the same name) and treats it as a fixable asset/export naming conflict rather than a fundamental limitation.

Kaze says he recently removed many engine bugs, is “slowly approaching zero engine bugs,” and got his compiler output down to zero warnings—framing this as a key stability/maintenance goal for the project as complexity rises.
findings.quote: I am slowly approaching zero engine bugs. I actually got my entire compiler down to zero warnings as well.

findings.summary: He optimizes runtime behavior execution by controlling actor execution order: actors run in the order they’re named in the level, so he renames/group-sorts actors with the same code to improve cache proximity. He argues ordering similar actors (e.g., multiple Shy Guys) helps performance more than interleaving disparate actor code.

Kaze discusses instruction cache behavior on N64 MIPS, claiming his game is optimized enough that Mario’s behavior loop stays resident in cache; he also rejects “entity component system” approaches as inefficient overhead for this context, preferring direct function/tick-based execution and careful ordering/alignment.
findings.quote: Turns out my game by itself is already so optimized that Mario's behavior loop never gets thrown out of cache.

findings.summary: He notes a visual workaround for an “N64-only bug” with z-clipping on grass overhangs: he changes how the grass geometry hangs to hide seams/clipping that wouldn’t be visible in typical preview contexts.

Fast64/material constraints: Kaze states environment color is disabled “because of the Fast64 issue,” so the team standardizes on primitive color multipliers for tint/variation. He explains the level’s lighting/variation is largely vertex colors plus primitive-color multiplication/interpolation rather than shadow textures.

He mentions they “no longer need patching” manually because they now have automatic patching, crediting F3DEX3—implying a tooling upgrade that reduces manual build/integration steps for assets or display lists.
findings.quote: I also don't need to do this patching anymore. Because we now have automatic patching. Very cool. Thank you, F3DEX3.

findings.summary: Kaze tunes aesthetic variation for repeated assets (e.g., bushes/planes) by random selection plus primitive-color-driven tint and brightness variance, balancing Biobak’s desire for less brightness/intensity against keeping slight variety so the environment doesn’t look flat or repetitive.

Yoshi integration issues: the imported Yoshi initially lacks collision/interaction and is spawned via the wrong list (“OBJ list spawner instead of surface”), and one mouth-open animation goes missing. Kaze identifies the failure mode and performs a quick model/animation fix sufficient to allow entering Yoshi, leaving the “talks twice” bug for later.

Kaze encounters N64 render constraints/bugs during asset import (e.g., “two textures in one cycle” illegal operation on a donut asset) and applies quick fixes like reducing texture cycles and rescaling the model to match the level.

He references boss pacing: he’s fine with the “second boss” being easy to avoid but considers making it slightly more dangerous, indicating ongoing difficulty tuning rather than locking challenge early.

A visual artifact with alpha/opacity appears darker/weirder in certain render backends; Kaze suspects either an emulator/backend bug or mismatch between Blender/preview and in-game alpha behavior, and postpones deeper diagnosis.

Course 10 layout changes force collision work: because many objects/warp holes moved, Kaze concludes a new collision map is required for the reworked area to be playable; he decides to finish this collision work off-stream due to time.

biobak.summary: Provides a substantial Course 10 (C10) rework with a new changelog and many actor/asset updates; prompts Kaze’s re-import pass and color/brightness tuning decisions.

Gives art-direction feedback on repeated assets (bush/plane colors, brightness, outlines) and on mechanical setpieces like a collapse-floor that now slides sideways (scratch marks imply motion direction).
Sends updated Yoshi assets that require re-hooking armature/animations and resolving export/material issues during integration.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentions being “banished” to the basement by Zeina, a small window into their day-to-day dynamic while he streams/works.
Kaze references a recurring couple joke: Zeina calls a sausage alone a “hot dog,” which Kaze disputes, illustrating their casual back-and-forth during dev time.

findings.summary: Challenges/queries Kaze’s cache/performance reasoning, prompting Kaze to explain his instruction-cache measurements and actor ordering strategy in more detail.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Turns out my game by itself is already so optimized that Mario's behavior loop never gets thrown out of cache.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze explains how far he’s pushed engine/runtime optimization on N64 by measuring instruction cache behavior and then designing around it (actor ordering, alignment).

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I am slowly approaching zero engine bugs. I actually got my entire compiler down to zero warnings as well.
memorable_quotes.context: A maintenance milestone mindset: stability and cleanliness as the project grows, implying a deliberate engineering push rather than only content production.

key_stories.title: Course 10 rework integration reveals pipeline and engine constraints
key_stories.summary: Kaze starts integrating Biobak’s updated Course 10 files and immediately hits recurring export/material errors (palette/too many colors, broken textures). He diagnoses a naming collision (duplicate texture names), fixes it, and continues import/testing while applying N64-specific visual workarounds.
key_stories.challenge: Asset imports intermittently break due to tool/export constraints (Fast64/material rules, duplicate names), and N64-only rendering quirks (z-clipping, alpha differences) don’t always appear in the same way in preview tools.
key_stories.process: He downloads Biobak’s new changelog/files, re-exports/tries again, identifies duplicate texture names as the cause, then validates in-game and makes targeted geometry tweaks to hide N64 z-clipping seams.
key_stories.outcome: Import proceeds with known constraints in mind; Kaze continues tuning and prepares for heavier follow-up work (collision remap) caused by the rework.

key_stories.title: Yoshi becomes usable again, but edge-case dialogue/animation bugs remain
key_stories.summary: After importing an updated Yoshi, Kaze finds missing collision/interaction and a broken/missing mouth-open animation. He corrects the spawn/list issue and performs a small model/animation edit so the player can enter Yoshi, postponing deeper issues like doubled dialogue triggers.
key_stories.challenge: Character integration requires multiple synchronized parts (model, armature, animations, interaction/collision) and can fail subtly when object lists or animation data are incomplete.
key_stories.process: Kaze inspects in-game behavior, predicts the failure mode (“OBJ list spawner instead of surface”), fixes the configuration, then edits the model/animation setup to restore the missing animation state.
key_stories.outcome: Yoshi is functional enough for progression; remaining bugs (talking twice, possible shy-guy-eating flag oddities) are logged implicitly for later.

open_questions.topic: Actor execution ordering as a performance strategy
open_questions.context: Kaze says actors execute in order of their level names and he renamed/grouped similar actors to improve cache proximity, claiming measurable benefits on N64.
questions: When did you discover that actor name/order affected execution order—was this an engine design choice you made, or a pre-existing behavior you decided to exploit?
How much performance headroom did this gain in real scenes (fps, CPU time, RSP/RDP load), and what profiling tools/metrics did you use to validate it?
Did this optimization change how level designers (including Biobak) are allowed to name/place actors to avoid accidental regressions?

open_questions.context: Kaze says he no longer needs manual patching because “we now have automatic patching,” crediting F3DEX3.
questions: What exactly was being manually patched before (display lists, texture tables, segment addresses, bank layout), and what does the new automatic system do end-to-end?
Who implemented/integrated the automatic patching (you vs. Sauraen/others), and what failure cases still require manual intervention?
How did this change day-to-day collaboration with artists (fewer constraints, faster iteration, fewer ‘it broke in-game’ moments)?

open_questions.topic: Fast64 limitations driving material rules (environment color disabled)
open_questions.context: Kaze states environment color is disabled due to a Fast64 issue, so the team relies on primitive color multipliers plus vertex colors for lighting/variation.
questions: What is the specific Fast64 issue that forces environment color off (export bug, incorrect combine mode setup, runtime mismatch)?
How much did this constraint shape the project’s art direction (e.g., leaning into vertex-painted lighting, limiting dynamic lighting effects)?
Are there any scenes/levels where you felt the loss of environment color most, and did you build custom workarounds?

open_questions.topic: Collision workflow after major level reworks
open_questions.context: Because many Course 10 objects/warp holes moved, Kaze concludes a new collision map must be created; he ends stream planning to finish it off-stream.
questions: What’s your collision authoring pipeline (Blender → Fast64 → export), and what tends to break when geometry shifts late in development?
How do you budget collision triangle count vs. accuracy for N64 performance/memory, and what are your ‘must-have’ collision details?
Do you have any automated checks/tests to catch missing collisions (like the initial Yoshi collision issue), or is it purely playtest-driven?

open_questions.topic: Yoshi dialogue triggering twice and shy-guy-eating flag oddities
open_questions.context: After getting Yoshi usable, Kaze notices Yoshi “talks twice” and suspects something around object lists/flags, plus weirdness when eating a Shy Guy.
questions: What’s the underlying state machine for Yoshi interactions (actions/subactions/flags), and what recent engine changes might have caused the double-trigger?
Is the ‘talk twice’ bug tied to cutscene flags, object list changes, or the new actor grouping/order optimizations?
How important is Yoshi’s interaction polish to the overall feel of the hack (as a ‘respectful’ modernization of Mario 64’s NPC logic)?
